subject: Cooking
title: Food Taboos: Why We Won't Eat Certain Things
description: A 1-minute de-risking session on Food Taboos: Why We Won't Eat Certain Things.

hook.text: 2 billion people eat insects daily. Others gag at the thought. The difference is culture, not biology.

buildup.text: Food taboos are culturally transmitted rules about what is and isn't acceptable to eat.

discovery.text: Hindus avoid beef, Muslims and Jews avoid pork, many Westerners reject insects â€” all for cultural reasons.

twist.text: There's no nutritional basis for most food taboos. Insects are higher in protein per gram than beef.

climax.text: Disgust is the enforcement mechanism â€” once a taboo is internalized, violating it triggers physical revulsion.

punchline.text: What you won't eat says more about your culture than your stomach.
